questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department due to a seizure. The patient's wife reports that during the past 3 weeks, he has been complaining of headaches. She also notes that he has been “acting strange” and has had difficulty walking over the past few days. His medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Physical examination shows the patient has postictal confusion but is responsive. The patient dies two days later secondary to respiratory arrest despite appropriate interventions. An autopsy is performed, and gross examination of the brain is shown below:  



Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons

Histopathological examination of this patient’s lesion is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Concentrically arranged spindle cells in a whorled pattern with areas of calcifications
Hypercellular areas of spindle cells alternating with hypocellular myxoid areas
Large abnormal lymphocytes infiltrating perivascular spaces
Thin-walled capillaries with minimal intervening parenchyma
Pleomorphic tumor cells surrounding an area of central necrosis

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation (seizures associated with progressive headache, weakness, and personality changes occurring rapidly over the course of several weeks), in addition to the characteristic gross morphology seen on autopsy, is consistent with the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM).   

GBM, or grade IV astrocytoma (astrocyte origin), is a highly malignant primary brain tumor with an approximately 1-year median survival. On histology, the tumor stains positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and is characterized by “pseudopalisading” pleomorphic tumor cells bordering central areas of necrosis, hemorrhage, and/or microvascular proliferation. On gross morphology, tumors are often large, poorly defined, and have areas of necrosis and hemorrhage.  On imaging, GBM is seen as a ring-enhancing lesion, because the contrast-enhancing tumor cells form a ring to surround the necrotic center, which does not take up contrast. The tumor can cross the corpus callosum, leading to a midline shift and causing a mass effect
.

Option Analysis

❌ Concentrically arranged spindle cells in a whorled pattern with areas of calcifications:
Incorrect: These histological findings are consistent with meningiomas, which are common, typically benign tumors of arachnoid cell origin. Meningiomas are extra-axial (external to brain parenchyma) and may have a dural attachment. This patient autopsy shows an intra-axial tumor with central necrosis and hemorrhage, which favors the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme.   
❌ Hypercellular areas of spindle cells alternating with hypocellular myxoid areas:
Incorrect: These histological findings are consistent with a Schwannoma, a tumor of Schwann cell origin. It commonly arises at the cerebellopontine angle, involving both cranial nerves VII and VIII, but it can occur along any peripheral nerve. Patients present with sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. This patient’s autopsy shows an intra-axial tumor in the cerebral hemispheres with central necrosis, which favors the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme.   
❌ Large abnormal lymphocytes infiltrating perivascular spaces:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with primary central nervous system lymphoma, a rare form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma seen most commonly in immunocompromised patients (e.g. HIV). Typical locations include the corpus callosum, periventricular white matter, and basal ganglia, presenting as either solitary or multiple lesions. This patient is immunocompetent with a characteristic lesion on autopsy, which favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Thin-walled capillaries with minimal intervening parenchyma:
Incorrect: These histological findings are consistent with hemangioblastoma, a tumor of blood vessel origin. These tumors most often arise in the cerebellum and are associated with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. This patient’s tumor morphology and location favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Pleomorphic tumor cells surrounding an area of central necrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to progressive lethargy, drowsiness and vomiting. His parents state he had been complaining of progressive headaches and worsening vision for the past several months. Height, weight and head circumference are at the 50th percentile for age. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears drowsy. Fundoscopic examination reveals bilateral papilledema. A brain MRI shows a lesion in the fourth ventricle with dilated ventricles. A stereotactic biopsy is performed, and the hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained sample is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
The progressive symptoms of hydrocephalus (lethargy, nausea, vomiting), the location of the tumor (4th ventricle), and the characteristic perivascular pseudorosettes in the biopsy specimen all point to an ependymoma.   

Ependymomas are invasive primary brain tumors that arise from the glial cells lining the ventricular system. Most commonly they occur in the 4th ventricle, leading to hydrocephalus. Ependymomas have the potential to disseminate throughout the central nervous system (CNS). Similar to medulloblastoma, the tumor can send metastasis to the spinal cord; however, on histology, the tumor is distinguished by perivascular pseudorosettes, not Homer-Wright rosettes (as seen in medulloblastoma). Pseudorosettes are neoplastic cells arranged around a blood vessel, while Homer-Wright rosettes are instead arrangements of small blue cells around a central core.  

Resection and adjuvant radiation therapy are the mainstays of treatment, except in very young patients. Chemotherapy is used only in very young children, patients with bulky residual disease, and recurrent or refractory tumors.  

Option Analysis

❌ Craniopharyngioma:
Incorrect: Craniopharyngiomas, while common, would be located in the pituitary fossa. Patients may present with bitemporal hemianopsia due to compression of the optic chiasm. Calcifications are often seen on imaging. On light microscopy, keratin pearls and cysts filled with cholesterol crystals (“motor oil”-like) are expected. The location and histology findings of this patient’s tumor favors another diagnosis.  
✅ Ependymoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Medulloblastoma:
Incorrect: Medulloblastomas are poorly-differentiated, highly-malignant tumors seen exclusively in children. These tumors commonly arise from the cerebellum and are characterized by Homer-Wright rosettes on histology. Common symptoms are ataxia, slurred speech, nystagmus, positive Romberg sign, and intention tremor. This patient’s imaging and histological findings favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Pilocytic astrocytoma:
Incorrect: Pilocytic astrocytoma, the most common pediatric primary brain tumor, is a benign low-grade tumor that usually arises in the cerebellar hemispheres or around the third ventricle. On imaging, cystic and solid components can be seen. Under light microscopy, it stains positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and shows eosinophilic corkscrew fibers (Rosenthal fibers). The location and histology findings of this patient’s tumor favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Oligodendroglioma:
Incorrect: Oligodendrogliomas are malignant tumors that generally occur in adults. They are rare tumors of oligodendrocyte origin that often grow in the frontal lobes. On histology, cells have round nuclei with clear cytoplasm forming a “fried egg” appearance and the capillaries of the tumor are arranged in a “chicken-wire” pattern. Calcifications may also be seen on imaging. The location, patient age, and histology findings favor another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to rhythmic jerking of the limbs followed by a period of drowsiness and confusion. Her husband reports she has been experiencing mild headaches for the past 2 years that occasionally awoke her from sleep, in addition to some noticeable left leg weakness over the past few months. The patient denies any trauma or vision changes. Neurological examination shows increased tone and hyperreflexia in the left lower extremity. Magnetic resonance imaging of the head is obtained and reveals a right parasagittal intracranial mass. The patient undergoes a biopsy of the lesion, and the results are shown below:  

 

Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following cell types is most likely responsible for this patient’s lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a seizure, headaches, and evidence of a focal neurological deficit affecting the left lower limb (weakness, hypertonicity, and hyperreflexia). These features combined with a parasagittal mass seen on imaging, as well as the characteristic psammoma bodies seen on histology, suggests that this patient has a meningioma.  

Meningiomas are tumors of arachnoid cell origin that commonly grow in the parasagittal region external to the brain parenchyma (extra-axial), often having a dural attachment (“tail”). On histology, the tumor is composed of spindle cells concentrically arranged in a whorled pattern and have characteristic psammoma bodies (laminated calcifications). The tumor can be asymptomatic, or may present with seizures or focal neurologic deficits. Treatment includes resection and/or radiosurgery.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Oligodendrocyte cells:
Incorrect: Oligodendrogliomas are tumors of oligodendrocyte origin that often grow in the frontal lobes. On histology, cells have round nuclei with a clear cytoplasm forming a “fried egg” appearance, and the capillaries of the tumor are arranged in a “chicken-wire” pattern. This tumor location as well as appearance on histology favors the diagnosis of meningioma.  



Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons 
✅ Arachnoid cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Endothelial cells:
Incorrect: Hemangioblastomas are uncommon, slow-growing tumors, which typically occur in the cerebellum, brainstem, or spinal cord. Hemangioblastomas can occur both sporadically and as a component of von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease. On histology, hemangioblastomas are compohused of an extensive vascular network and neoplastic "stromal cells,” which are embedded among the vascular channels. The neoplastic cells have abundant cytoplasm packed with lipid vacuoles.  



Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Schwann cells:
Incorrect: Schwannomas are tumors of Schwann cell origin that grow along the peripheral nerves, most commonly involving both cranial nerves VII and VIII. On histology, it stains positive for S-100 and characterized by a biphasic architecture: Antoni A-dense, hypercellular areas containing spindle cells, alternating with Antoni B-hypocellular myxoid areas. This patient’s lesion location and histological appearance favors the diagnosis of meningioma.  



Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons  
❌ Ependymal cells:
Incorrect: Ependymomas are a group of tumors that arise from glial cells lining the ventricular system. They most commonly occur in the 4th ventricle, leading to hydrocephalus. On histology, cells form characteristic perivascular pseudorosettes.

 


Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text:
A 54 year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to a seizure. People in the homeless shelter who witnessed the event report that she fell to the ground and started having rhythmic jerking movement of the limbs. Her medical history is unknown. Physical examination reveals the patient to be dishevelled, confused, and barely responsive. Computed tomography of the head is obtained and shown below before (left) and after (right) the addition of contrast (shown below):  



Credit: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely origin of this patient's primary tumor?
questions.solution:
This female patient with an unknown medical history is now presenting with seizure. Her CT shows multiple lesions at the gray-white matter junction, which are indicative of brain metastases.   

Brain metastases are the most common type of intracranial tumors in adults, accounting for more than 50% of brain tumors. The most common sites of primary tumors that spread to the brain are the following: lung > breast > melanoma, colon, kidney. Metastases are typically located at the junction of the gray-white matter where blood vessels decrease in diameter and trap clumps of tumor cells. Brain metastases also tend to occur at the "watershed areas" of arterial circulation. Common presenting symptoms include seizure, headache, cognitive dysfunction, focal neurologic deficits, and stroke.   

Option Analysis

✅ Breast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Liver:
Incorrect: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) sites of metastasis include the lung, abdominal lymph nodes, and bone. Brain metastasis, although possible, is very unlikely.   
❌ Brain :
Incorrect: Primary brain tumors are usually singular. Multiple lesions at the grey-white matter junction are most likely to be the result of metastasis rather than primary lesions.   
❌ Bone:
Incorrect: Metastatic cancers to the bone greatly outnumber primary bone cancer and include prostate, breast, kidney, thyroid and lung. Primary bone tumor metastasis to the brain is very unlikely.   
❌ Stomach:
Incorrect: The most common sites of metastasis for stomach cancer include the liver, peritoneal surfaces, and non-regional or distant lymph nodes. Metastasis to the brain and central nervous system, although possible, is much less common.   
❌ Thyroid:
Incorrect: Thyroid cancer is usually contained in the thyroid at the time of diagnosis. Common locations for metastasis include the local lymph nodes, lung, and bone. Spread to the brain, although possible, is rare.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician's office by his parents due to headaches and difficulty walking. The parents report that he had a viral infection 2 months ago, and since then he has had a mild headache, especially in the morning. They also state that he has become clumsier, and his school performance has declined. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 121/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a broad based gait and head bobbing. A horizontal nystagmus is present. Magnetic resonance imaging of the head and spine is obtained and shown below:  






Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

A biopsy of the mass is performed and shows blue cells palisading around a central core. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has metastatic medulloblastoma. The diagnosis is supported by the classic presenting signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g. headache), cerebellar signs (e.g., head titubation, nystagmus, broad-based gait), and imaging revealing a lesion in the cerebellum and spinal cord (“drop metastasis”). In addition, the histological biopsy depicts pathognomonic Homer-Wright rosettes. 

Medulloblastomas, the most common malignant primary brain tumor of childhood, typically occur in the cerebellum (infratentorial). Spreading to the spinal cord is common (“drop metastasis”), as seen in this patient. Medulloblastomas belong to the family of primitive neuroectodermal tumors (PNET), which are tumors of the undifferentiated nerve cells in the brain.  

Presenting symptoms typically include headaches, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, gait ataxia or truncal instability, limb clumsiness, dizziness, and double vision. Hydrocephalus may occur secondary to obstruction at the level of the fourth ventricle.  

Histopathology shows small blue cells arranged around a central core (Homer-Wright rosettes). This finding distinguishes the tumor from ependymomas, which classically have pervascular pseudorosettes, characterized by neoplastic cells arranged around a blood vessel.  




Credit: Wikimedia Commons 

Option Analysis

❌ Glioblastoma multiforme:
Incorrect: Glioblastoma multiforme theoretically can invade the spinal cord; however, this tumor is seen in the adult population. Also, it typically grows in the cerebral hemispheres and histopathology would show a “pseudopalisading” pattern of pleomorphic tumor cells, not Homer-Wright rosettes.   
❌ Pilocytic astrocytoma  :
Incorrect: Pilocytic astrocytoma, a low-grade astrocytoma, also occurs in the cerebellum and can metastasize to the spinal cord; however, histopathology would show glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) positive staining and Rosenthal Fibers.    
❌ Schwannoma:
Incorrect: Schwannoma is a tumor that typically grows along the peripheral nerves, not in the cerebellum. On histology, the tumor stains positive for S-100 and is characterized by biphasic architecture.  
❌ Meningioma:
Incorrect: Meningiomas commonly grow in the parasagittal region external to the brain parenchyma and may have a dural attachment. Histology shows spindle cells concentrically arranged in a whorled pattern and characteristic psammoma bodies (laminated calcifications).   
❌ Craniopharyngioma:
Incorrect: Craniopharyngioma is a supratentorial tumor derived from remnants of Rathke’s pouch (ectoderm). Histology shows keratin pearls and cysts filled with cholesterol crystals (“motor oil”-like).   
✅ Medulloblastoma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Ependymoma:
Incorrect: Ependymomas are tumors that arise from the glial cells lining the ventricular system. Most commonly it occurs in the 4th ventricle, leading to hydrocephalus. Similar to medulloblastoma, it can send metastases to the spinal cord; however, on histology, cells form characteristic perivascular pseudorosettes, not Homer-Wright rosettes (see main explanation).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is found to have an incidental brain mass after receiving a CT-scan of her head to investigate chronic sinusitis. The mass is located in the frontal lobe, occupying part of the white matter with areas of calcifications. She denies headaches or vision changes, and her medical history is non-contributory. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A biopsy of the mass is performed and reveals sheets of cells with round nuclei surrounded by clear cytoplasm, with delicate, branching capillaries and microcalcifications. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This asymptomatic patient is presenting with an incidental mass in the frontal lobe found on imaging, as well as a characteristic appearance on biopsy, which favors the diagnosis of a slow growing oligodendroglioma.  

Oligodendrogliomas are rare tumors (approximately 5% of all neuroepithelial tumors of the CNS) of oligodendrocyte origin that often grow in the frontal lobes. Oligodendrogliomas are slow-growing, infiltrative tumors that may be silent for many years. Focal neurologic deficits and headache are uncommon at the time of diagnosis. On histology, cells have round nuclei with clear cytoplasm forming a “fried egg” appearance and the capillaries of the tumor are arranged in a “chicken-wire” pattern. Calcifications, which are characteristic of oligodendroglial tumors, but are neither sensitive nor specific, can be visualized on computed tomography (CT).  



Credit: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Glioblastoma multiforme:
Incorrect: Glioblastoma multiforme is a common, highly malignant primary brain tumor with poor survival rates. On histopathology, it stains positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and shows “pseudopalisading” pleomorphic tumor cells that border areas of central necrosis and hemorrhage. This patient is asymptomatic, and the histological appearance favors the diagnosis of oligodendroglioma.  
❌ Meningioma:
 Incorrect: Meningiomas are tumors of arachnoid cell origin that commonly grow in the parasagittal areas of the brain and may have a dural attachment (extra-axial). On histology, spindle cells are arranged concentrically in a whorled pattern along with “psammoma bodies” calcifications. Although this tumor biopsy shows calcifications, these are nonspecific, and this patient's lesion is intra-axial, which favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Hemangioblastoma:
Incorrect: Hemangioblastomas are uncommon, slow-growing tumors, which typically occur in the cerebellum, brainstem, or spinal cord. On histology, hemangioblastomas composed of an extensive vascular network and neoplastic "stromal cells" which are embedded among the vascular channels.  
❌ Schwannoma:
Incorrect: Schwannomas are tumors of Schwann cell origin that grow along the peripheral nerves, most commonly involving both cranial nerves VII and VIII. On histology, these tumors stain positive for S-100 and are characterized by biphasic architecture: Antoni A-dense, hypercellular areas containing spindle cells alternating with Antoni B-hypocellular myxoid areas.   
✅ Oligodendroglioma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pilocytic astrocytoma:
Incorrect: Pilocytic astrocytomas are benign, low-grade astrocytomas. They are the most common primary brain tumor in childhood, although they are occasionally seen in older individuals as well. Typically, they are found in the posterior fossa (e.g. cerebellum). On imaging, they are composed of cystic and solid components. On histology, they stain positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and show eosinophilic corkscrew fibers (Rosenthal fibers).

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man comes to the office due to hearing loss, a persistent “buzzing” in his ears, and the feeling of unsteadiness on his feet for the past 2 months. Physical examination shows reduced hearing bilaterally and an ataxic gait. An MRI is obtained and shown below:  


Credit: Radiopaedia

This patient's condition is most likely related to a mutation involving which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with bilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and ataxia, with imaging that shows bilateral masses at the cerebellopontine angle, most likely has bilateral vestibular Schwannomas (acoustic neuromas).  

 Schwannomas arise from Schwann cells, which are a subtype of glial cells. When they arise from the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VII and VIII) at the cerebellopontine angle, they are called vestibular Schwannomas or acoustic neuromas. Bilateral vestibular Schwannomas (acoustic neuromas) occur specifically in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).   

NF2 is an autosomal dominant disease caused by a mutation of the NF2 tumor suppressor gene  on chromosome 22. The NF2 gene produces merlin, also called schwannomin, a cell membrane-related protein that serves as a tumor suppressor. Manifestations of NF2 include bilateral vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas), juvenile cataracts, meningiomas, and ependymomas.   



Option Analysis

❌ Neurofibromin :
Incorrect: Loss of neurofibromin protein is the cause of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Mutation of the NF1 gene on chromosome 17 leads to absent/reduced production of neurofibromin protein, resulting in the classic presentation of diffuse cutaneous neurofibromas, intellectual disability, Lisch nodules, optic gliomas, and pheochromocytomas. Neurofibromin belongs to a family of guanosine triphosphate hydrolase (GTPase)-activating proteins that are involved in signaling pathways. This patient's presentation however, is consistent with neurofibromatosis type 2, not type 1.  
✅ Merlin:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ PTEN:
Incorrect: Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) gene is a negative regulator of the phosphoinositide-3-kinase (PI3K)-AKT pathway, which is critical for cell proliferation, cell cycle progression, and apoptosis. Loss of function of this gene contributes to breast, prostate, and endometrial cancer development.   
❌ Hamartin:
Incorrect: Hamartin protein is the gene product of the TSC1 gene on chromosome 9, which is widely expressed in normal tissues. Hamartin forms a complex with the tuberin protein that is encoded by the TSC2 gene. It is hypothesized that loss of tuberin (or a functional tuberin-hamartin complex) results in the loss of inhibitory regulation on the cell cycle, leading to tuberous sclerosis, not neurofibromatosis type 2.  
❌ WT1:
Incorrect: WT1 gene is located on chromosome 11. The WT1 gene product is a transcription factor expressed in the developing kidney, testis, and ovary, and it appears to play a role in the development of genitourinary tissues. Mutations of the WT1 gene and its product are associated with Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to delayed growth. His parents report that he is often bullied in school, because he is much smaller than his peers. He was at the 50th percentile for weight and height one year ago, but he is now at the 20th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows decreased vision in the lateral eye fields of both eyes. Magnetic resonance imaging is obtained and shows cystic lesions with areas of calcifications within the suprasellar region. This patient’s lesion is most likely a derivative of which of the embryological layers?
questions.solution:
This patient, who presents with growth delay, bitemporal hemianopsia and imaging showing a suprasellar cystic calcified mass, most likely has a craniopharyngioma.  

Craniopharyngiomas are benign, low grade tumors with a bimodal age distribution. Clinical features typically include headaches, endocrine abnormalities (deficiencies of growth hormone, gonadotropins, thyroid stimulating hormone, and/or adrenocorticotropic hormone), and bitemporal hemianopsia (compression of the optic chiasm). Imaging reveals a cystic, calcified parasellar lesion; histological analysis shows cysts filled with turbid “motor oil”-like fluid and cells filled with keratin (“keratin pearls”).  

Craniopharyngiomas arise from remnants of Rathke's pouch. During embryological development, the surface ectoderm forms the oropharynx. The small outpouching of the roof of the oropharynx, termed Rathke's pouch, gives rise to the adenohypophysis (anterior pituitary).  



Option Analysis

❌ Neural tube:
Incorrect: The neural tube is a hollow structure formed by the invagination of the neuroectoderm and gives rise to various central nervous system components, as seen in the table below. Prominent intracranial tumors that arise from the neural tube include glioblastoma multiforme, oligodendrogliomas, pilocytic astrocytomas, and ependymomas.   
✅ Surface ectoderm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neural crest  :
Incorrect: The neural crest is derived from the neural plate, which itself is derived from the neuroectoderm. Prominent intracranial tumors that arise from neural crest cells include schwannomas and meningiomas.   
❌ Endoderm:
Incorrect: The endoderm is the innermost layer of the 3 primary germ layers and gives rise to the epithelial lining of various organs, which can be seen in the table below.   
❌ Mesoderm:
Incorrect: The mesoderm is the middle layer of the 3 primary germ layers and its various derivatives can be seen in the table below. Prominent structures that are found in the central nervous system include the dura mater (the only layer of the meninges that is not derived from the neural crest) as well as the notochord, which becomes the nucleus pulposus of intervertebral discs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of severe headaches, which are worse in the morning and have been ongoing for the past month. They are 8/10 in severity and throbbing in quality. She has also experienced associated nausea and vomiting. Moreover, her ability to concentrate has declined, and she has experienced word-finding difficulty. Vital signs are within normal limits. Strength and sensation are intact in the upper and lower extremities. An MRI scan of the brain is obtained, which reveals a multicentric, hemorrhagic tumor in the right temporal lobe. She is prescribed an oral glucocorticoid to decrease cerebral edema associated with the mass. Which of the following glucocorticoids has the most prolonged duration of action?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids can be classified according to their duration of action. Of the answer choices listed, dexamethasone has the longest course of action. It can be administered orally, intravenously, or via inhalation. It is often used to treat inflammation, acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis, cerebral edema (as in this clinical vignette), shock, allergic conditions, and multiple myeloma. It is very potent and can cause marked suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. For this reason, it is also used in the dexamethasone suppression test, which assists in diagnosing Cushing syndrome.  



Option Analysis

❌ Hydrocortisone:
Incorrect: Hydrocortisone is a short-acting glucocorticoid that can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. It has the lowest potency among glucocorticoids. It can systemically treat acute adrenal insufficiency and topically treat skin rashes.
❌ Prednisone:
Incorrect: Prednisone is one of the intermediate-acting glucocorticoids. The intermediate-acting glucocorticoids include prednisone, prednisolone, and methylprednisolone. These can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. They are of intermediate potency and can be used to treat inflammatory conditions such as asthma and autoimmune disorders.
❌ Prednisolone:
Incorrect: Prednisolone is one of the intermediate-acting glucocorticoids. The intermediate-acting glucocorticoids include prednisone, prednisolone, and methylprednisolone. These can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. They are of intermediate potency and can be used to treat inflammatory conditions such as asthma and autoimmune disorders. Moreover, since prednisolone is the biologically active form of prednisone, it is often used in patients with liver disease who cannot convert prednisone to prednisolone.
❌ Methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: Methylprednisolone is one of the intermediate-acting glucocorticoids. The intermediate-acting glucocorticoids include prednisone, prednisolone, and methylprednisolone. These can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. They are of intermediate potency and can be used to treat inflammatory conditions such as asthma and autoimmune disorders.
✅ Dexamethasone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency room with incoherent speech. He is accompanied by his spouse, who states the patient has had a headache for two weeks and that he appeared confused this morning. His medical history includes atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and diabetes. His current medications include warfarin, lisinopril, and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. He returned from a trip to India a month ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98%. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Extraocular movements are within normal limits. His speech is intangible, but he can pick up a pen and copy a picture of a matchstick when prompted. Axial MRI scan reveals a butterfly-shaped intracranial mass crossing the corpus callosum. Following a biopsy, he is initiated on procarbazine, lomustine, and vincristine regimen. Which of the following adverse effects can be expected in this patient?

choices.text: Progressive dyspnea on exertion, S3 on cardiac examination
Asymptomatic decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction
Bleeding from the gums, fever, and pallor

questions.solution:
This patient presents with expressive motor aphasia, chronic headache, and an MRI revealing a butterfly-shaped intracranial mass crossing the corpus callosum consistent with glioblastoma multiforme.  

Procarbazine is a non-cell, cycle-specific alkylating agent indicated in treating Hodgkin lymphoma, glioblastoma multiforme, and other brain tumors. Its mechanism of action is not well defined. Myelosuppression is the most common, acute, dose-limiting toxicity of this agent. Resultant effects include depression of all cell lineages resulting in pallor secondary to anemia, bacterial infections due to leukopenia, and bleeding from mucous membranes due to thrombocytopenia. Granulocyte stimulating factors such as filgrastim are commonly administered in case of bone marrow suppression. Other adverse effects of procarbazine include pulmonary toxicity and secondary leukemia. Procarbazine has also been shown to induce mild reversible encephalopathy and neuropathy. 

Option Analysis

❌ Progressive dyspnea on exertion, S3 on cardiac examination:
Incorrect: These symptoms indicate a presentation suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy. Cardiotoxicity is anticipated with the administration of doxorubicin and daunorubicin.
❌ Asymptomatic decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction:
Incorrect: Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody instrumental in treating HER2-positive breast cancers. Reversible cardiotoxicity is a known complication of its use and manifests as a reduction in left ventricular ejection fraction. 
❌ Transaminitis :
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can cause hepatotoxicity at all doses. Patients may present with transaminitis or fibrosis. Hepatotoxicity is not associated with procarbazine, vincristine, or lomustine use. 
✅ Bleeding from the gums, fever, and pallor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infertility :
Incorrect: Alkylating agents like cyclophosphamide are known to exert long-term effects on male and female fertility. Women on cyclophosphamide experience premature menopause and infertility, while men may have a reduction in sperm count. Infertility is not a known adverse effect of procarbazine, lomustine, or vincristine.

questions.text: A 40- year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his roommate for evaluation of  convulsions. His roommate states the patient was experiencing dizziness and was walking “funny” earlier in the day. He does not have a fever, rash, vomiting, or headache. His medical history includes allergic rhinitis, AIDS, and primary CNS lymphoma treated with methotrexate, teniposide, carmustine, prednisone, and rituximab. He last received treatment two days ago. His current medications include HAART and over-the-counter decongestants. He uses intravenous heroin and smokes cocaine occasionally. He consumes two to three beers daily; his last drink was three hours ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98%. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Extraocular movements are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals needle tracks in both arms. Mucous membranes are moist. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. He appears tired and lethargic but responds to verbal commands. He moves all his extremities spontaneously, and deep tendon reflexes are symmetric. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication/substance responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Indirect neurotransmitter that increases the concentration of sympathomimetic agents
Inhibition of the reuptake of sympathomimetic biogenic amines
Cross-linking of DNA strands in the central nervous system
Withdrawal from a CNS depressant acting on GABA receptors

questions.solution:
This patient’s neurological symptoms suggest carmustine toxicity in the setting of treatment for primary CNS lymphoma. Carmustine belongs to the class of medications called nitrosoureas that act as alkylating agents. These medications require bioactivation of cytochrome P450 enzymes in the liver, cross the blood-brain barrier and induce DNA damage by creating interstrand cross-links.    

Nitrosoureas like carmustine and lomustine are potentially neurotoxic when administered in high doses and include adverse effects such as convulsions, dizziness, and ataxia.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Indirect neurotransmitter that increases the concentration of sympathomimetic agents:
Incorrect:  Amphetamines like methamphetamine act as indirect neurotransmitters by incorporating in cytoplasmic vesicles and increasing concentrations of sympathetic agents like norepinephrine and epinephrine. Methamphetamine intoxication should be considered in patients with psychomotor agitation (including seizures), diaphoresis, hypertension, tachycardia, and dilated pupils. 
❌ Agonist at mu receptors :
Incorrect: Opioids like morphine act on mu receptors distributed throughout the central and peripheral nervous system. Opioid intoxication presents with depressed mental status, respiratory drive, and miotic pupils. Opioid withdrawal can present with a dysphoric mood, diarrhea, increased lacrimation, tachycardia, dilated pupils, and hypertension. 
❌ Inhibition of the reuptake of sympathomimetic biogenic amines :
Incorrect: Cocaine is a stimulant that increases the availability of sympathomimetic biogenic amines like dopamine, epinephrine, and norepinephrine by blocking presynaptic reuptake.  Acute cocaine intoxication can present with psychomotor agitation (seizures, coma), chest pain, and vitals reflecting hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and dilated pupils.   
✅ Cross-linking of DNA strands in the central nervous system:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Withdrawal from a CNS depressant acting on GABA receptors:
Incorrect: Alcohol withdrawal can present with withdrawal seizures typically six to forty-eight hours after drinking has ceased. Other symptoms, such as agitation and tremors, are likely. Physical findings include hypertension, tachycardia, and diaphoresis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the local paramedics after a motor vehicle collision. He was found approximately 1 hour after the accident occurred. At the scene, the patient was awake and complained of pain in his back and legs. His temperature is 35.6°C (96.1°F), his pulse is 106/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/88 mm Hg. Glasgow coma scale is 15. On physical examination, the patient is awake, his speech is clear and appropriate, and he has normal breath sounds over bilateral lung fields. He has palpable, equal femoral pulses. Multiple abrasions are noted over the neck, shoulders, abdomen, and legs. The chest wall is nontender. The abdomen is mildly tender. The pelvis is stable, but he has extensive swelling and tenderness of the right thigh. The patient has multiple scalp lacerations that continue to ooze. Which of the following best describes the location of the bleeding from the scalp seen in this patient?

choices.text: Between the arachnoid mater and dura mater
Between the brain and arachnoid mater
Between the scalp skin and epicranial aponeurosis
Between epicranial aponeurosis and loose connective tissue
Between the periosteum and epicranial aponeurosis

questions.solution:
The scalp is highly vascularized by the branches of the external and internal carotid arteries, which course within layer two of the scalp, the subcutaneous connective tissue layer between the skin and the epicranial aponeurosis. Most bleeding comes from the superficial temporal artery and the occipital artery.  

Scalp lacerations usually bleed profusely, primarily the result of abundant anastomosis. In addition, the severed arteries do not contract when they are cut because the vessel lumens are held open by the dense connective tissue in the second layer of the scalp.    

Scalp wounds can be classified as:  
  •  Superficial scalp wounds: Do not gape because of the strength of the underlying aponeurosis, which holds the margins of the wound together 
  •  Deep scalp wounds: The scalp is lacerated in the coronal plane. The wounds gape because of the contraction of the frontalis and occipitalis muscles in the opposite directions. This aponeurotic layer of the scalp is often tightened during cosmetic surgery (e.g., “facelifts”) to help reduce wrinkles in the face and forehead. 

Option Analysis

❌ Between the arachnoid mater and dura mater:
Incorrect: Bleeding between the arachnoid mater and dura mater is known as subdural hemorrhage. It usually results from tears in bridging veins that cross the subdural space. Patients with large bleeds may present with signs of increased intracranial pressure. External bleeding is not seen. 
❌ Between the brain and arachnoid mater:
Incorrect: Subarachnoid hemorrhage develops between the brain and arachnoid mater. External bleeding is not seen. 
✅ Between the scalp skin and epicranial aponeurosis:
 Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Between epicranial aponeurosis and loose connective tissue:
Incorrect: The nerves and arteries of the scalp course within layer two, the subcutaneous connective tissue layer between the skin and the epicranial aponeurosis. The loose connective tissue (layer four) contains the emissary veins. It is a “danger area” because it allows the spread of infection to the intracranial structures. 
❌ Between the periosteum and epicranial aponeurosis:
Incorrect: Subgaleal hemorrhage results from bleeding from emissary veins between the periosteum and the epicranial aponeurosis. It can occur in neonates during birth and presents as diffuse, progressive, fluctuant scalp and neck swelling.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for follow-up regarding facial pain. The patient states, “The symptoms have become so bothersome, I can’t sleep at night and none of the medications I’m taking are working.” The patient reports intermittent stabbing pain along the left side of her face below the eye brought on by brushing her teeth or putting makeup on. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates reproducible pain with light tapping of the upper teeth. Tapping of the lower teeth does not elicit pain. Which of the following nerves is implicated in the pathogenesis of this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of trigeminal neuralgia, a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of pain in the trigeminal nerve distribution (CN V). This patient’s pain is localized to CN V's maxillary nerve branch (V2).

Trigeminal neuralgia is a poorly understood condition but is thought to be due to trigeminal nerve root compression. Clinically, this disease presents as recurrent, sudden onset stabbing pain along the trigeminal nerve's V2 (maxillary) or V3 (mandibular) branches, with onset triggered by minor stimuli such as touch, wind, or chewing food. Trigeminal neuralgia is a unilateral condition; however, it can occur bilaterally in usual cases, typically caused by multiple sclerosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Maxillary nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mandibular nerve:
Incorrect: The mandibular nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve, provides sensory information to the lower jaw and cheek while also providing motor function to several muscles of mastication. While this branch of the trigeminal nerve may also be implicated in cases of trigeminal neuralgia, this patient’s exam suggests disease limited to the maxillary nerve branch.  
❌ Ophthalmic nerve:
Incorrect: V1 supplies sensory function to the scalp and forehead, the upper eyelid, the conjunctiva and cornea of the eye, the nose. It is not commonly implicated in cases of trigeminal neuralgia (<5% of cases).  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It is not implicated in the pathogenesis of trigeminal neuralgia.  
❌ Glossopharyngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Motor function of cranial nerve IX or the glossopharyngeal nerve includes innervation of the stylopharyngeus muscle, elevating the larynx and pharynx during speaking and swallowing.

questions.text: After a high-speed motor vehicle accident, a 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department. The patient was restrained when her vehicle was struck from the passenger side by another vehicle traveling approximately 60 mph (97 km/h). The patient’s primary survey is intact. A secondary survey demonstrates a bleeding laceration and a palpable depression over the temporal bone. The patient reports diminished sensation over her left forehead, nose, mouth, and jaw. The patient’s jaw deviates towards the left when asked to open her mouth. Which of the following cranial nerves is most likely damaged based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features consistent with a trigeminal nerve injury (CN V)--likely at the trigeminal root or ganglion. The trigeminal nerve carries both sensory and motor innervation to the face and is divided into three major branches: the ophthalmic branch (V1), maxillary branch (V2), and mandibular branch (V3).

The V1 supplies sensation to the scalp and forehead, the upper eyelid, the conjunctiva and cornea of the eye, and the nose. The V2  provides sensation to the area over the maxilla, nasal cavity, sinuses, palate, and mid-face. Lastly, V3  provides sensory information to the lower jaw and cheek while also providing motor function to several muscles of mastication. Thus, patients with injury to the trigeminal root will have absent sensory information over the entire ipsilateral face and weakness or wasting of the muscles of mastication. Weakness of these muscles will result in ipsilateral deviation of the jaw when opened. In addition, V1 provides sensory input regarding the reflex arc for the corneal reflex. Thus damage to this branch or the trigeminal root will result in an absent corneal reflex.  

Option Analysis

❌ CN  I:
Incorrect: The optic nerve, or cranial nerve, provides sensory information regarding sight to the brain.  
✅ CN V:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CN VII:
Incorrect: Cranial nerve VII, or the facial nerve, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.  
❌ CN IX:
Incorrect: Motor function of cranial nerve IX, or the glossopharyngeal nerve, includes innervation of the stylopharyngeus muscle, elevating the larynx and pharynx during speaking and swallowing.  
❌ CN X:
Incorrect:  The vagus nerve innervates several of the striated muscles of the larynx and pharynx. Damage to this nerve does not result in jaw deviation. Moreover, damage to this nerve would result in autonomic dysfunction.

questions.text: A medication is currently under study in rat models that is found to have potent cardiovascular effects, including increasing the heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac output at intermediate doses. Further investigation of this medication reveals it carries structural homogeneity with a neurotransmitter responsible for activating the direct pathway of the striatum of the brain. This medication has also been demonstrated to carry which of the following physiologic properties?

choices.text: Increased water reabsorption in the collecting tubules

questions.solution:
This medication under study is shown to increase the heart rate, cardiac contractility, and blood pressure while also activating the direct nigro-striatal pathway. This is consistent with dopamine. When administered peripherally and at lower doses, it carries significant sympathomimetic effects. Notably, it causes dilation of renal arteries.     

Dopamine, now seldom used in modern clinical practice, was historically used for patients in shock with concomitant renal failure due to its agonistic effects on D1 receptors. This includes causing splanchnic and renal vasodilation. As a sympathomimetic, dopamine carries alpha and beta effects, resulting in the aforementioned effects on cardiac function. Notably, alpha effects tend to predominate at higher doses, resulting in vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure. Additional uses for dopamine include treatment of unstable bradycardia and shocks (e.g. cardiogenic, refractory distributive).    

Primary toxicities of dopamine include cardiovascular disturbance and arrhythmias. Central nervous system side effects are not observed when dopamine is given parenterally due to minimal penetration through the blood-brain barrier.  

Option Analysis

✅ Dilation of renal arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Laryngospasm:
Incorrect: Laryngospasm is a known side effect of the NMDA-receptor antagonist ketamine. It is not a known side effect of dopamine.  
❌ Increased water reabsorption in the collecting tubules:
Incorrect: Increased water reabsorption in the collecting tubules of the kidneys is one of the known effects of vasopressin via agonism at V2 receptors. Dopamine does not carry effects on V2 receptors.  
❌ Increased gastric acid secretion:
Incorrect: Increased gastric acid secretion is mediated via H1 receptors, which are not affected by dopamine.  
❌ Dystonia:
Incorrect: Anti-dopaminergic agents, such as benztropine, may precipitate dystonic reactions, but dopamine does not.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman undergoes CT angiography of the head and neck. The patient is found to have a partial occlusion of the structure indicated by the arrow:  


Image reproduced from Osmosis.org.  

Which of the following blood vessels is primarily supplied by the affected structure?
questions.solution:
This patient has a partial occlusion of the right vertebral artery. The vertebral arteries supply blood to the posterior cerebral circulation vessels, such as the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.  

The vertebral arteries arise from the subclavian arteries and travel towards the cranium through the transverse foramina of the cervical vertebrae. Afterward, the vessels pass through the foramen magnum into the cranial cavity.  

First, the vertebral arteries give off a branch called the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which supplies the medulla and parts of the cerebellum. Both vertebral arteries then unite into a single vessel called the basilar artery at the medulla. As the basilar artery ascends, it first gives off the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA), which supplies the lateral pons and parts of the cerebellum.  

Then, the basilar artery sends small branches called pontine arteries to supply the mid-pons. Near the midbrain above, the basilar artery gives off the right and left posterior cerebral arteries (PCA), which supply the occipital lobes of the brain. The PCAs eventually give rise to the posterior communicating arteries, which merge with the internal carotid arteries to connect the posterior circulation with the anterior circulation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The arrow points to the vertebral artery, which supplies blood to the posterior cerebral circulation. In contrast, the anterior cerebral arteries are part of the anterior circulation provided by the internal carotid arteries. 
❌ Lenticulostriate artery:
Incorrect: The lenticulostriate artery is a branch of the middle cerebral artery. Since the lenticulostriate artery is part of the anterior cerebral circulation, it is supplied by the internal carotid artery.
❌ Middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The arrow points to the vertebral artery, which supplies blood to the posterior cerebral circulation. In contrast, the middle cerebral arteries are part of the anterior circulation and supplied by the internal carotid arteries.   
❌ Ophthalmic artery:
Incorrect: The ophthalmic artery is part of the anterior cerebral circulation and supplied by the internal carotid artery. 
✅ Anterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old woman develops weakness in the right hand following a stroke. Grip strength is 3/5 in the right hand and 5/5 in the left hand. The lower extremities are unremarkable. A coronal cross-section of the brain is shown below:



Which of the following regions of the motor homunculus is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has weakness in the right upper extremity. A stroke involving the mid-lateral portions of the left motor cortex would account for this deficit.  

The proportion of neurons in the primary motor cortex utilized by each body part is represented by a humanoid figure called the motor homunculus. Starting at the superior medial part of the primary motor cortex, the lower extremities are represented first. The upper extremities and head are progressively represented as one moves laterally through the primary motor cortex.   

In addition, there is a sensory homunculus, which represents the proportion of sensory fibers in the primary somatosensory cortex received from each part of the body. Like the motor cortex, the superior medial parts of the somatosensory cortex receive signals from the lower extremities. In contrast, the more lateral portions of the cortex receive signals from the upper extremities and head.  



Option Analysis

❌ Region A:
Incorrect: The medial portion of the motor cortex is responsible for controlling the lower extremities. In contrast, this patient has weakness in the right upper extremity. 
❌ Region B:
Incorrect: The medial portion of the motor cortex is responsible for controlling the lower extremities. In contrast, this patient has weakness in the right upper extremity. 
❌ Region C:
Incorrect: The motor cortex region denoted by Region C would control movements in the left upper extremity. In contrast, the left motor cortex controls the right upper extremity, which is where the patient is experiencing weakness.
✅ Region D:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Region E:
Incorrect: The lateral portions of the motor cortex are responsible for controlling the movement of structures such as the head, neck, tongue, and larynx. This region of the motor cortex does not control upper extremity movement.
❌ Region F:
Incorrect: The lateral portions of the motor cortex are responsible for controlling the movement of structures such as the head, neck, tongue, and larynx. This region of the motor cortex does not control upper extremity movement.

questions.text: A group of investigators is studying the pathway of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow in the ventricular system. Which of the following best describes the direction of CSF flow?

choices.text: Lateral ventricle → third ventricle → fourth ventricle → subarachnoid space
Subarachnoid space → third ventricle → fourth ventricle→ lateral ventricle
Fourth ventricle → lateral ventricle → third ventricle → subarachnoid space
Lateral ventricle → subarachnoid space → third ventricle → fourth ventricle
Lateral ventricle → fourth ventricle → subarachnoid space → third ventricle

questions.solution:
Choroid plexuses form cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the ventricles. Once formed, CSF flows from the lateral ventricles to the third ventricle via the interventricular foramen. It then circulates to the fourth ventricle through the cerebral aqueduct. CSF exits the fourth ventricle and enters the subarachnoid space via the two lateral apertures and single medial aperture. CSF is returned to the venous circulation via the arachnoid villi.  



Option Analysis

✅ Lateral ventricle → third ventricle → fourth ventricle → subarachnoid space:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subarachnoid space → third ventricle → fourth ventricle→ lateral ventricle:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Cerebrospinal fluid is produced in the ventricles and subsequently transported into the subarachnoid space.
❌ Fourth ventricle → lateral ventricle → third ventricle → subarachnoid space:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. CSF from the lateral ventricles empties first into the third ventricle and then the fourth. Finally, CSF passes from the fourth ventricle to the subarachnoid space via the medial aperture and lateral apertures.
❌ Lateral ventricle → subarachnoid space → third ventricle → fourth ventricle:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. CSF from the lateral ventricles empties into the third and then the fourth ventricle. Finally, it passes from the fourth ventricle to the subarachnoid space via the medial aperture and lateral apertures.
❌ Lateral ventricle → fourth ventricle → subarachnoid space → third ventricle:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. CSF from the lateral ventricles empties into the third and then the fourth ventricle. Finally, it passes from the fourth ventricle to the subarachnoid space via the medial aperture and lateral apertures.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of facial weakness. Earlier in the morning, she had trouble drinking coffee as it was drooling from the right side of her face. Her partner mentioned that her face was drooping, and she noticed that she could not move her mouth or eyebrows on that side. She has not had hearing loss, ringing sensation in the ears, or difficulty walking. She underwent a right superficial parotidectomy for the resection of a pleomorphic adenoma in the parotid gland two days ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows asymmetry of the face with smiling. There is also loss of the right nasolabial fold, with drooping of the eyelids and lips on the right side. The rest of the examination is noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the findings seen in this patient?

choices.text: Upper motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve

questions.solution:
This patient has new-onset right-sided facial weakness causing drooling from the right side of the face, facial droop, asymmetric smile, and inability to move the eyebrow after recent surgery involving the parotid gland. She likely suffered intraoperative facial nerve injury causing ipsilateral facial muscle paralysis.

During its extracranial course, the motor component of the facial nerve enters the parotid gland, where it forms the parotid plexus. This plexus then divides into the terminal branches to innervate the facial muscles. Injury to this area (e.g., secondary to trauma, iatrogenic, etc.) can lead to ipsilateral paralysis of the facial muscles. Since the nerves to the stapedius and chorda tympani branch proximal to this area, the patient does not experience hyperacusis or abnormalities in taste.

Patients with paralysis need to keep the eye lubricated (with artificial tears) and closed while sleeping (with a taping of the eye) to prevent corneal trauma and desiccation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Tick-borne illness:
Incorrect: Early disseminated Lyme disease can involve CN VII, leading to facial nerve palsy. However, it is usually accompanied by a macular rash, arthralgia, and aseptic meningitis. Considering the recent surgery, the temporal association of symptoms makes it a more likely cause.
❌ Upper motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve:
Incorrect: Unilateral UMN lesions (e.g. stroke) only affect the lower part of the face due to dual UMN control of the upper face, thereby sparing it. This patient has paralysis of upper facial muscles, making UMN lesion less likely.
❌ Reactivation of a dormant virus:
Incorrect: The major complication of reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus is the Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which typically includes the triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicles in the auditory canal and auricle. This patient does not have otalgia, and physical examination of the auricle and auditory canal is unremarkable.
✅ Recent surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tumor at the cerebellopontine angle:
Incorrect: Even though a tumor at a cerebellopontine angle (e.g. schwannoma) can sometimes involve facial nerve, it is usually preceded by the symptoms of CN VIII impingement (i.e., tinnitus, ataxia, vertigo, or sensorineural hearing loss), none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of excruciating headaches. The headaches began three days ago and have progressively worsened. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 152/90 mmHg, and pulse is 97/min. On physical examination, the headache is worsened with the Valsalva maneuver. No signs of trauma are present over the skull. CT imaging is obtained and reveals thrombosis within the portion of the superior sagittal sinus overlying the occipital lobe. The affected area of the dural venous system is primarily innervated by which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
This patient has headaches secondary to a dural sinus thrombosis. The thrombosis is in the portion of the superior sagittal sinus overlying the occipital lobe, which is located in the posterior cranial fossa and innervated by the ophthalmic nerve (CN V1).

The dura mater has a nerve supply that varies between the anterior, middle, and posterior cranial fossa. All three trigeminal nerve branches innervate dura mater overlying the anterior cranial fossa. Dura mater overlying the middle cranial fossa is innervated mainly by the mandibular nerve (CN V3) and some innervation from the maxillary nerve (CN V2).

The supratentorial dura of the posterior cranial fossa and the tentorium cerebelli are innervated by the ophthalmic nerve (CN V1). In contrast, the infratentorial dura is innervated by a combination of the vagus nerve (CN X) and cervical plexus. 

Of note, signals from the dura mater travel along the sensory fibers of these nerves and can be referred to as cutaneous areas also supplied by the same nerve fibers. As a result, intracranial pathologies can present with referred pain over the face.  



Option Analysis

✅ Ophthalmic nerve (CN V1):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Maxillary nerve (CN V2):
Incorrect: The maxillary nerve (CN V2) provides innervation to the anterior and middle cranial fossa. However, it does not provide innervation to the portion of the superior sagittal sinus overlying the occipital lobe, which is located within the posterior cranial fossa.
❌ Abducens nerve (CN VI):
Incorrect: The abducens nerve (CN VI) assists with eye movements. The abducens nerve does not provide innervation to the dural venous sinus system.
❌ Facial nerve (CN VII):
Incorrect: The facial nerve (CN VII) has a wide variety of functions. These include controlling facial movements, lacrimation, salivation, and relaying taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the facial nerve does not innervate the dural layers. 
❌ Vagus nerve (CN X):
Incorrect: The posterior cranial fossa can be subdivided into the supratentorial and infratentorial fossas. The infratentorial fossa is innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X) and branches of the cervical plexus. In contrast, the supratentorial fossa, which contains the superior sagittal sinus, is innervated by the ophthalmic nerve (CN V1).

questions.text: During a neurology lecture, students learn that the thalamus is the central relay station for all ascending sensory information, except for olfaction. Which of the following thalamic nuclei relays auditory information?
questions.solution:
The thalamus is the central relay station for all ascending sensory information except olfaction. The medial geniculate nucleus relays auditory information from the tectum's superior olive and inferior colliculus to the primary auditory cortex. The functions of the other thalamic nuclei are summarized below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Ventral posterolateral nucleus:
Incorrect: The ventral posterolateral nucleus relays vibration, pain, pressure, conscious proprioception, light touch, and temperature information from the spinothalamic and dorsal columns/medial lemniscus to the primary somatosensory cortex.
❌ Ventral posteromedial nucleus:
Incorrect: The ventral posteromedial nucleus relays facial and taste sensations from the trigeminal and gustatory pathways to the primary somatosensory cortex.  
❌ Lateral geniculate nucleus:
Incorrect: The lateral geniculate nucleus relays visual information from the optic nerve (CN II), optic chiasm, and optic tract to the primary visual cortex (occipital lobe).
✅ Medial geniculate nucleus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ventral anterior and lateral nuclei:
Incorrect: The ventral anterior and lateral nuclei relay motor information from the basal ganglia and cerebellum to the motor cortices (frontal lobe).

questions.text: A 65-year-old person is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset right-sided weakness. They were eating dinner when, suddenly, they could not lift their fork. Upon standing up, the patient’s right side gave away, and they fell onto the carpet. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia for which the patient takes amlodipine, metformin, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 190/100 mmHg. Physical examination shows deviation of the eyes to the left side. Motor strength is 0/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left side. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of this patient’s ocular findings?

choices.text: Lesion involving the right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF)
Lesion involving the right frontal eye field
Lesion involving the left frontal eye field
Lesion involving the right paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF)
Lesion involving the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF)

questions.solution:
This patient presents with right-sided hemiplegia and deviation of the eyes to the left. They likely have a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory stroke involving the left frontal eye field.  

The frontal eye field refers to an area of the frontal lobe involved in visual field perception and voluntary eye movements. It plays a crucial role in conjugate horizontal gaze and saccades (fast eye movements).  

In order to look to the right, the left frontal eye field synapses to the contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) via the superior colliculus. The efferent pathway from the PPRF passes to the right lateral rectus motor neurons (via the CN VI nucleus), resulting in abduction of the right eye. Excitatory signals are also sent to the contralateral medial rectus motor neurons (CN III) via the contralateral medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), resulting in adduction of the contralateral (left) eye.  

Horizontal gaze palsy is typically caused by either a contralateral frontal eye field lesion or an ipsilateral PPRF lesion.   

The middle cerebral artery supplies the lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere. Strokes involving the middle cerebral artery (MCA) can lead to lesions that also involve the frontal eye field. Clinically, the eyes will deviate towards the side of the lesion (left-sided MCA stroke with right-sided hemiplegia means that eyes will be deviated to the left). In contrast, a lesion involving the PPRF results in ipsilateral gaze palsy (inability to look towards the side of the lesion).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Lesion involving the right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF):
Incorrect: A lesion affecting the unilateral MLF impairs adduction of the ipsilateral medial rectus, resulting in internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) – a conjugate horizontal gaze palsy.
❌ Lesion involving the right frontal eye field:
Incorrect: Preferential gaze is controlled by the contralateral frontal eye field. This patient presents with an inability to gaze to the right, which is consistent with a lesion in her left frontal eye field.
✅ Lesion involving the left frontal eye field:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lesion involving the right paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF):
Incorrect: A lesion involving the PPRF results in an ipsilateral gaze palsy (inability to look towards the side of the lesion). A lesion in this area does not explain the patient’s right-sided motor deficits.
❌ Lesion involving the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF):
Incorrect: Lesions involving the PPRF result in ipsilateral gaze palsy (inability to look towards the side of the lesion). This patient has left-sided eye deviation (rather than the inability to look left), and a lesion in this area would not explain their right-sided motor deficits.

questions.text: A group of researchers is examining the different parts of the kidney histologically. A segment of the kidney is taken and visualized under the microscope as shown below. The arrow in the picture is pointing towards which of the following cells?

choices.text: Parietal layer of the bowman’s capsule

questions.solution:
The renal corpuscle is the area in the nephron where the blood is initially filtered. This filtered fluid is then modified in the renal tubules to produce urine.  

The renal corpuscle is made of a tuft of capillaries called the glomerulus, surrounded by a capsule called the bowman’s capsule. The filtered fluid from the glomerulus goes into the bowman’s space.  

Lining the glomerulus is a fenestrated layer of endothelial cells; these fenestrations allow the filtered fluids and molecules to pass. The bowman’s capsule is lined with two layers: the outer layer, called the parietal layer, which is made of flat simple squamous epithelium, and the visceral layer, made of specialized cells called podocytes. These podocytes line around the endothelial cells of the glomerulus and have a particular function in filtration by their foot processes (which are elongated structures from the cells that form a physical barrier to prevent larger molecules like proteins from being filtered). The oval basophilic nucleus can identify the podocytes. Finally, another type of cell can also be found in the glomerulus called the mesangial cell. These cells have darker and more round nuclei than the podocytes and function in regulating blood flow to the kidney and in immune defense and repair.  


Option Analysis

✅ Podocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mesangial cells  :
Incorrect: Although mesangial cells can be challenging to differentiate from podocytes, they usually have a round and darker nucleus, unlike the podocytes, whose nucleus is more oval.  
❌ Endothelial cells  :
Incorrect: Endothelial cells line the glomerulus capillary. The arrow is pointing at a podocyte.  
❌ Parietal layer of the bowman’s capsule  :
Incorrect: The parietal layer of the bowman’s capsule is the outer layer of the capsule that consists of squamous epithelium. The arrow is pointing toward podocytes.  
❌ Alpha intercalated cells  :
Incorrect: Alpha intercalated cells are found in the collecting tubules, not the glomerulus.

questions.text: A medical student is studying the physiology and source of aldosterone. Which of the following is true regarding the effects of aldosterone?

choices.text: Increases reabsorption of sodium and bicarbonate in the proximal convoluted tubules
Inhibits the cotransport system (Na+/K+/2Cl−) of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Increases sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion

questions.solution:
In volume-depleted states formation of angiotensin II (ATII) occurs by activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). ATII has myriad effects, including the release of aldosterone from the zona glomerulosa cells of the adrenal cortex. Aldosterone is a mineralocorticoid that exerts the following effects:
  
  • Binds to intracellular receptors in principal cells of collecting ducts to stimulate expression of genes, including those coding for the sodium-potassium ATPase pumps. These protein pumps found on the basal surface of these cells establish a concentration gradient that pulls sodium (and water) out of the lumen of the tubule (via ENaC channels) and into the blood while excreting potassium.  
  • Aldosterone increases hydrogen ion secretion from alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule by upregulating H+ ATPase activity. 

Option Analysis

❌ Increases reabsorption of hydrogen ions:
Incorrect: Aldosterone increases hydrogen ion secretion from alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule by upregulating H+ ATPase activity.  
❌ Only causes water reabsorption:
Incorrect: Isolated water reabsorption is a function of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which acts on the principal cells of the collecting ducts of nephrons.  
❌ Increases reabsorption of sodium and bicarbonate in the proximal convoluted tubules:
Incorrect: The absorption of sodium and bicarbonate in the proximal convoluted tubules is stimulated by angiotensin II, which upregulates the activity of sodium hydrogen (Na+/H+) exchanger.  
❌ Inhibits the cotransport system (Na+/K+/2Cl−) of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle:
Incorrect: This cotransport system is inhibited by loop diuretics (e.g. furosemide). Aldosterone does not act on this cotransporter.  
✅ Increases sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A researcher is evaluating dynamic changes of the kidney during pregnancy. He notes that as the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) increases both the filtration rate and excretion of certain molecules are affected. Which of the following changes in glucose clearance would be expected as a result of these changes?

choices.text: Increased filtered glucose and glucosuria occurs at lower plasma glucose concentrations
Increased filtered glucose and decreased glucose reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules
Increased filtered glucose, but all filtered glucose will be reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubules

questions.solution:
Glucose is normally filtered by the glomerulus. In the proximal convoluted tubule, sodium-glucose linked transporters (SGLT) reabsorb all filtered glucose into plasma.

Glucose filtration is directly proportional to the plasma concentration of glucose, so if plasma glucose increases, the quantity of filtered glucose increases. Similarly, if the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) increases, the amount of filtered glucose will also increase. This occurs in physiologic states that result in dilation of the afferent arterioles (e.g. pregnancy).

SGLT transporters can reabsorb all filtered glucose until the plasma concentration of glucose reaches 200 g/dL. At a plasma glucose concentration of 375 g/dL, all SGLT channels are saturated, and glucose begins appearing in urine (glucosuria).  


Option Analysis

✅ Increased filtered glucose and glucosuria occurs at lower plasma glucose concentrations:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased filtered glucose and decreased glucose reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules:
Incorrect: Due to increased glucose filtration, there will be increased reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubules.  
❌ No change in glucose filtration:
Incorrect: An increased GFR will cause an increase in the filtration of glucose.  
❌ Decreased glucose filtration:
Incorrect: Increased GFR will cause an increased filtration of glucose.  
❌ Increased filtered glucose, but all filtered glucose will be reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubules:
Incorrect: Due to increased glucose filtration, there will be increased reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubules.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the effects of angiotensin II on the human body. Which of the following is true regarding the effects of angiotensin II?

choices.text: Stimulates the secretion of oxytocin from the posterior pituitary gland
Stimulates the activity of sodium/hydrogen ATPase in the proximal convoluted tubule

questions.solution:
The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is one of the mechanisms by which the cardiovascular system and kidneys attempt to maintain normal arterial blood pressure by controlling blood volume. Angiotensin II (ATII) has the following effects:

  • Vasoconstriction: ATII stimulates ATII receptors to type I on arteriolar smooth muscle to cause vasoconstriction. 
  • Constriction of efferent arterioles: ATII preferentially constricts efferent arterioles more than afferent arterioles to preserve glomerular filtration rate (GFR) in volume-depleted states. However, chronically high levels of ATII can cause constriction of both, leading to a decline in GFR.
  • Increased Na+/H+ exchanger activity in proximal convoluted tubule (PCT): ATII stimulates the reabsorption of sodium ions and water by stimulating PCT cells. 
  • Stimulation of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion from the posterior pituitary gland: ADH acts on the principal cells of the collecting ducts in nephrons to reabsorb water via increased expression of aquaporins on the luminal surface of these cells. 
  • Stimulation of thirst: ATII acts directly on the hypothalamus to stimulate thirst to improve volume status. 
  • Stimulation of aldosterone secretion: ATII stimulates aldosterone from zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex, which increases hydrogen ion secretion from alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule. Aldosterone also acts on the principal cells of the collecting ducts, where it causes increased sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion. 

Option Analysis

❌ Stimulates the secretion of oxytocin from the posterior pituitary gland:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II stimulates the secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the posterior pituitary gland, which then acts on the principal cells of the collecting ducts of nephrons to reabsorb water.  
❌ Inhibits the secretion of aldosterone:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II stimulates (not inhibits) the secretion of aldosterone from the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex, which increases hydrogen ion secretion from alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule. Aldosterone also acts on the principal cells of the collecting ducts, where it causes increased sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion.  
✅ Stimulates the activity of sodium/hydrogen ATPase in the proximal convoluted tubule:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibits arteriolar smooth muscle contraction:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II stimulates, not inhibits, arteriolar smooth muscle contraction.  
❌ Constricts peritubular capillaries:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II  improves the glomerular filtration rate in volume-depleted states by preferentially constricting efferent arterioles more than afferent arterioles. It does not affect peritubular capillaries.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the pathway that results in the generation of angiotensin II and, in particular, is studying the angiotensin-converting enzyme. Endothelial cells of which of the following organs contain the greatest concentration of angiotensin-converting enzyme?
questions.solution:
The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is one of the main physiologic mechanisms by which the cardiovascular system and kidneys attempt to maintain normal arterial blood pressure by controlling blood volume. When blood gets supplied to the renal artery, it reaches the afferent arterioles, and in the walls of the afferent arterioles are specialized smooth muscle cells called juxtaglomerular (JG) cells that secrete renin when stimulated.

Renin cleaves a large protein synthesized by the liver, angiotensinogen, to produce angiotensin I. Angiotensin I then travels in circulation to reach endothelial cells of the lungs and kidneys, which have an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) on their surface. ACE cleaves angiotensin I into an 8-amino acid peptide called angiotensin II (AT II).

Option Analysis

✅ Lungs:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Liver:
